review_title: Good place to to start or end career, but not for mid-level
job_title: Project Manager in College Park, MD
pros: Great benefits - and 7.25% retirement contribution, 25 days off per year, 14 holidays off per year, tuition remission, etc. The work can be rewarding and their is a great atmosphere and comradery. Good place to either get your foot in the door, or a nice place to end your career and coast to retirement. Great work life balance
cons: Be prepared for a ton of bureaucracy, Years of service is more important than work ethic. Not a good place to spend the middle of your career, or else you can get complacent and waste away. Pay can be lower than industry standards if you do not push for more.

review_title: Impact of current leadership's decisions remains to be seen...
job_title: Anonymous Employee in College Park, MD
pros: As I imagine with all University environments, it's inspiring to work at a research institution whose mission includes the "creation of new knowledge."  Impressive students make me feel hopeful for the future.  Fantastic benefits and flexibility.
cons: Current upper ranks do not always seem to be in agreement/get along and the decision making seems to be much more top down and opportunistic than under the previous administration.  Fairly typical leadership transition stuff -- whether the large sweeping decisions current management is making will be good for Maryland in the long run remains to be seen.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: We work to help the students to achieve their goals and strike out on a new life with the knowledge they obtained in UMD.  The casual dress and atmosphere. How the campus supplies help to those who need it regarding para transit and the ride on buses. The extra breaks like Spring and Christmas.
cons: No pay raises or cost of living increases.  Everything is going up in America and the paychecks are staying down.  It makes life tougher to live.  University of Maryland is losing more and more people to a better paying jobs that give cost of living and pay raises.

review_title: UMD is a great place to work (except for the salary)!
job_title: Coordinator in College Park, MD
pros: In general, employees are highly competent and passionate about the work that they do at the University of Maryland. The university is very prestigious and research-oriented. Although it has not always had a strong reputation for supporting diversity and inclusion, it is currently making great headway to recruit, hire, and mentor traditionally underrepresented groups of student, professionals, and faculty.
cons: In such a large university setting, the silo mentality runs rampant and some offices are unwilling or unable to coordinate with others. Budget trends within the state's shortfall has seen many employees fleeing for higher paying jobs elsewhere in higher education and in the public and private sectors in the D.C. metro region.

review_title: UMBC is not all that great to work at. Average at best.
job_title: in Baltimore, MD
pros:
Summers off because it is so hot and humid in July and August.
High level of student diversity.
The good students, are very good.
cons:
Despite being a research university, it is still a very immature academic culture compared with older universities. 
Lack of collegiality.
Faculty are overworked on many levels.
Too many poor decisions are made in a panic or rush.
General ignorance of various areas at the university.
Lack of communication between various areas and entities of the university.
Because of lack of communication, there are many missed opportunities to share resources and expertise.
University staff never answer the phone.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in College Park, MD
pros: I had the opportunity to maintain a very flexible schedule that helped with work - life balance. Offered tuition remission and multiple opportunities for training and educational advancement.
cons: I started in a contigent I position eventually moving into a contigent II position, but I was never offered permanency due to constraints of grant funded position. There are a lot of politics and cliques within the university which is common with larger organizations, so if you know the right people it's easier for you to move up the ladder despite your work history or your previous contributions made.

review_title: The University and Journalism School is not good place
job_title: Anonymous in College Park, MD
pros: There is nothing good about this institution at all
cons: The journalism school here is not good at all. There is favoritism and preferential treatment in the institution and especially, journalism school among all individual parties including the audience that being served at this institution.  Discrimination is rampant here. The faculty has discriminated against all individuals with disabilities and especially individuals with learning disabilities. This institution does not care about them at all and do not treat them with respect and with the same fairness as other employees. Disabled individuals at this institution at all levels are ridiculed and are unfairly treated. This institution does not give them any opportunities and assistance as other individuals. All the faculty and employees have gotten away with disability discrimination.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in College Park, MD
pros: The staff I worked with are very understanding, flexible with student hours, and kind. It's the easiest commute for a student living on campus, and the experience can help you prepare for off-campus opportunities if you're a student.
cons: As for the cons, you have to deal with the decentralized campus. It can be hard to connect and reach out to other employees when you're trying to get something done. Almost a month into my job, and I've yet to get my own work computer. It's a slow campus when it comes to IT.

job_title: GRA in College Park, MD
pros: Flexible work schedule & nice people. They will pay for your classes and for your living expenses while you perform research for them. This is only if you are in a field such as engineering. Make sure to get your work done and to stay on task. Also, it is best if you can find housing very close to campus or the commute will be horrible! Look at the metro and bus routes and see if you can use public transportation instead of driving to work. It will save you gas money and many headaches! Overall, UMD is great and terps rule!
cons: The commute is horrible- traffic around 495 sucks!

review_title: Academic Career at University of Maryland,  a post doc perspective
job_title: Post Doc Fellow in Baltimore, MD
pros: Excellent faculty, open communications, close to several other excellent universities, city life (pro in my case),  diverse graduate and post doc groups, very dynamic, lots of potential
cons: Faculty structure is still ivory tower, limited financial resources outside of the NIH, hiring freezes and furlough.

review_title: This is definitely a changing school looking to up its national reputation. A great place to come and learn.
job_title: Office Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: This is a big school and you will meet a lot of interesting people. Having said that, there are many clubs and organizations to find your niche.
cons: Some of the buildings on campus are really nice. It is great if you have classes in one of those buildings but you are out of luck if you are in one of the older buildings. It can get really hot especially in the summer as sometimes the air conditioning does not work. Also, you hear all the time about state budget issues since the school is a public institution.

job_title: Peer Health Educator in College Park, MD
pros: You work with an amazing diverse team, lots of group/ team work,  your peer group and leader really want you to succeed and offer you all the resources you need to be the best educator possible. Lots of check-ins to learn more information, learn about whats working and whats not, and they ensure that your health/well-being is great!  You give many presentations and your public speaking abilities grow substantially.
cons: The presentations can get tough because you need to motivate a crowd of college kids, but once you have that down it is smooth sailing!

job_title: Graduate Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: Working in my Department within Student Affairs has been a wonderful experience, namely because of the wonderful people that you end up working with. Heavy interaction with students, both current and prospective, which is exciting in its own right.
cons: Sometimes you are left scratching your head to some management decisions, but for the most part their decisions are understandable. There is currently an exodus of mid-level staff, which is unfortunate, but an excellent opportunity for prospective employees.

job_title: Associate Director in College Park, MD
pros: My department is great with an amazing director.   Our department purpose is clear and I get to use my skill everyday and feel my department cares about me and my development
cons: PARKING!!!!    The Senior campus leadership in particular the President appears to treat staff like a commodity and seems more interested in being a urban developer than the leader of a great univeristy

review_title: A decent way to get by
job_title: in College Park, MD
pros:
-Supervisors and boss are very understanding about taking time off
-The pay isn't bad for a student position
-Supervisors and boss will make your work schedule work with your class schedule
cons:
-There is little to no communication from the bottom to the top of the organization
-There is little to no communication between people in the same department or group
-Management, all the way up, does not ever stop to check the quality of work of their employees/delegates

review_title: Not bad for some extra money
job_title: Research Associate in College Park, MD
pros: Student life, interpersonal interactions, and just a general easy going atmosphere within the campus.  The work can be interesting at times but this was only occasionally. The pay is good for stupid simple jobs.
cons: Not challenging work so you can get bored easily, not easy to grow within the company, and the pay isn't fantastic and almost impossible to get a raise.

job_title: Master Patrol Officer in College Park, MD
pros: Good benefits, especially education benefits. Great people to work with! Real police work is done here. If you apply yourself and work hard you will grow and succeed here.
cons: The administration is a bit out of touch with Patrol level officers and doesn't communicate/address their concerns well. There was a big compression issue with salary which essentially kept loyal, long term officers' salaries down. Hopefully this has been addressed by now.

review_title: Customer service does not equal education.
job_title: Academic Adviser in Adelphi, MD
pros: Work in a college environment, tuition remission, and it sure looks good on a resume.
cons: Absolutely no flexibility whatsoever, Management out of touch with its workers and students, employee treated with disdain, no plan for advancement, no health insurance, minimal vacation days, no unpaid leave, change is not managed well, one hand does not know what the other hand is doing.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: This is a nice place to do research as doctoral student. I enjoy the green campus. I found the faculty to be generally nice. For a computational researcher, I also had really good access to computing resources.
cons: The most disappoint part are that they are no windows in most of the offices of graduate research assistants. Due to lack of funds in the department, free stuffs like coffee are no longer so.

review_title: University of Maryland Police/Department of Public Safety
job_title: Supervisor in College Park, MD
pros: Some of my coworkers were highly motivated students who were on their way to government and law enforcement careers. Other coworkers are great, friendly people who make the awful conditions more bearable.
cons: In general, if you're looking for opportunity, look elsewhere. Pay is low when compared to similar jobs, and advancement is nearly nonexistent. Widespread incompetence has limited (if any) repercussions. Expect to lose all work/life balance.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Park, MD
pros:
Good location, next to DC, convenient to everything you need.
Good program as a public school, much less expensive than private schools. 
Good computing facilities, enough for research.
cons:
Fundings are limited these years. A large portion of the Maryland government funding goes to JHU, which is a private school.

Hard to get internship if one is in economy or IT areas. Less companies in the area.

Aged faculty inside the department. Less fresh blood.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: Most of the faculty you work with is nice, on average, and the work load for teaching assistant is on average low, so students have plenty of time to do research.
cons: Depending on the professor you work with, he/she can ask you to make unreasonable tasks, such as requiring a TA with F1 visa to work more than 20 hours a week.

job_title: in Baltimore, MD
pros: It is a fun and flexiable enviorment and team to work with.  The adminstrators are easy to get along with and make it a pleasure to go into the office everyday.
cons: Promotions move slowly and people can get frustrated and apathetic due to this.  It is a state job so there are negative aspects to that as well.

review_title: Low Pay, Difficult Working Environment, Good People
job_title: Coordinator in College Park, MD
pros: The benefits are not bad, but they don't make up for the low salary because many companies offer these benefits also.
cons:
The pay is usually $20K-40K below the outside academia salaries.
If you are disabled and have trouble walking, you will have enormous trouble getting to your assigned work place due to the parking being so far from some of the buildings. At least they have finally placed elevators in all of the buildings.

job_title: Professor in College Park, MD
pros: As a faculty member, you can make your own future.  The university's location is excellent for collaborative research.  Once a tenured professor, you have job security.
cons: Academia is no longer a bastion of free thought and shared governance is more talk than action. Due to the recession, employees will not receive raises and will be furloughed for the third straight year.

job_title: Technology Consultant in College Park, MD
pros: Very flexible hours with respect to class, homework, and other job opportunities you are pursuing. If you are applying for jobs or internships they respect that and work to get your shifts covered. Good experience working with and in front of people, usually highly stressed out because some piece of technology isn't working. During down time you can do homework.
cons: The work expected is simple so if you try too hard you will get frustrated that people around you are lazy and above you are incompetent/ineffective.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Baltimore, MD
pros: The work environment is great! People are friendly and encouraging. This is a great university to grow as a scientist with plenty of journal clubs and professors that are willing to take a significant amount of time teaching students and postdocs. I've heard that in other universities postdocs are left to fend for themselves and do not feel as if they are a part of the community. That is definitely not the case here.
cons: The pay sucks, but then again, that's what 11 years of college gets you nowadays :p

review_title: Senior Management needs to improve Leadership and Ideas
job_title: Coordinator in College Park, MD
pros: I am on staff in one of the colleges and have loved it because of the people I work with and the environment.  Benefits are really great.
cons: Little to no chance for advancement for staff.   An entrenched "rankism" exists -- the belief that only a PhD can do the job.  Management lacks ideas and eschews risk-taking or innovation.

job_title: Fire Protection Engineering in College Park, MD
pros: Great Engineering school. I love the small community of Fire Protection Engineering. The larger engineering school has great support with opportunities to go abroad, get involved at home, and plenty of tutoring and other helpful resources.
cons: The supporting departments have fairly poor teaching. The Physics department is abysmal, The math department is hit or miss depending on the professor, and the chem department could also be better.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty Member in College Park, MD
pros:
I have been teaching in the Professional Writing Department for several years.
I love the flexibility in my schedule, and the opportunity to connect with students in small class settings about the skills they will need to success as emerging professionals.
cons: The pay and term-by-term uncertainty might be the most challenging part for part-time faculty to consider these opportunities.  But the collegial atmosphere and helpful staff are more than compensating for these shortcomings.

job_title: in Adelphi, MD
pros: Salaried employees have lots of time off; ample vacation and sick days, and many Federal holidays. The salaries are decent. Schedules are pretty flexible.
cons: The university seems intent on the quantity of its students as opposed to the quality of the education it provides. Additionally, many of the students probably shouldn't be pursuing higher education to begin with. Communication between management, senior management and staff is poor. The employees by and large are provincial and uninspiring. For those of you who live in the District, it's very difficult to work for the university if you don't have a car.

review_title: A good up and coming university
job_title: Research Scientist in College Park, MD
pros: The university of Maryland has improved greatly in the last 30 years.  Time was when the admissions policy was that if you had a diploma from a Maryland high school, you got in.  Those days have gone.  The university has done a nice job of attracting and, more importantly, retaining its top talent.  The university's students keep getting better, and they no longer lose top professors every year to more prestigious universities.  The university's position in the metropolitan area of the nation's capitol is an incredible asset for recruiting students and faculty.  Benefits, vacation and sick leave are excellent if you can take the time off.
cons: If you aren't a tenure-track professor, the place is not built for you, and you may find you have second class citizen status.  The whole place is geared toward helping tenure-track professors do research, publish, and improve their credentials.  Since that's the currency of academic achievement, it's understandable, but just be aware that it's their playground and you're in it.  With the economic crisis, salaries in recent years have stagnated, with no merit raises in several years and only one cost of living increase in the last 5.  Some staff positions, especially in the plant department, have had some serious problems with harassment.  These have been addressed to some extent.  Very few job reviews, and very little mentoring.

review_title: Potential for Success, but Rough Environment
job_title: Assistant Professor in Silver Spring, MD
pros: The potential for an assistant professor to succeed here exists. You have the bare minimum needed to succeed. The benefits are good. You'll meet some of the smartest undergrads anywhere. Some of the grad students are incredible as well.
cons: You'll meet some of the worst of the worst undergrads. The intellectual environment is not very collaborative across departments. It can be very rough for someone just starting out with little support for assistant professors. This might be department dependent.The quality of the grad students can be quite poor. Recruiting good postdocs is very hard.

job_title: Research Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: Lots of leadway for independent research.  Working under a PhD with extensive knowledge in the field.  Very relaxed managers and environment.
cons: There is no room for vertical movement within the system from this position.  You must go to graduate school in order to make lateral movements.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: ranked very high in the nation, and has very talented professors and students around to work with. Being a big campus, its a great diverse experience. Proximity to the capital is also a plus, both professionally and socially.
cons: The neighborhood around can be sketchy, and the graduate salaries are not very good. The working conditions, i.e. the work desk is kind of just something put together to make it work. Leaves a bad taste, but its not a deal breaker.

job_title: Senior IT Systems Analyst in College Park, MD
pros: Working at UMD consider a state employee with a lot of benefits such as a 3 weeks pay vacation and regular 2% living cost increase.  Depend where you work, flexible work hour and telecommute is available.  Also, allow us to attend out-of-state conferences as a part of career development.
cons: The salary is not comparable with private companies and there is no bonus.  Working environment is not as good as private companies especially for IT employees.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: In my various roles as a Graduate Research Assistant and Graduate Teaching Assistant, I have gain hands-on experience and have learned more than I did from the courses that I have taken.  Much of the work was self-directed, which forced me work through problems independently and, ultimately, gain more confidence in my own work.
cons: Sometimes it would have been nice to feel more like a part of a "team."  The majority of my work was completed independently, so I don't feel very connected to the university, the research team, etc.

job_title: Bus Driver in College Park, MD
pros:
Mostly Driving College Students so no passenger issues

Small company so everyone knows everybody 

Tuition Remission ( if full time) 

Since employed for University of Maryland you have full access to most facilities and discounted access to the rest

No mandatory uniform -allowed to wear regular wardrobe (within reason)
cons:
Low pay compared to other CDL positions 

A lot of routes are short and redundant ( circles college campus)

Must constantly look out for pedestrians darting across the street at inappropriate times  ( college campus) 

High percentage of young student employees

job_title: Director in College Park, MD
pros: Diverse campus community. A mini-city. From deans to truck drivers, lawyers to housekeepers.  Million dollar coaches to over-extended support staff.
cons: Very stratified. If the various colleges could erect a wall around their building, they would be just as happy dealing only with their own.  There were definitely the haves and the have-nots. No clear over-arching administrative fabric--everyone had their own fiefdoms run the way THAT unit or college wanted it without consistency across the campus.  Some colleges or units were great, others just awful with the turnover to prove it!

review_title: Decent place to get some base experience
job_title: Student Software Engineer in College Park, MD
pros:
This pertains specifically to the Division of IT as a student employee. My recommendation is conditional from a student perspective, make sure to get other summer internship experience elsewhere before you graduate.

Will hire CS majors with little to no experience beyond Introductory level CS classes and good soft skills. Definitely recommend to freshman or sophomores looking to bolster their resume to apply to other internships. 

During the semester the work schedule is fairly flexible. Also the opportunity to work over the summer can be nice. 

I got along with pretty much everyone I worked with in the Division of IT. Good, supportive atmosphere open to answering questions. 

Good place to get some web development experience, front end and back end. They have a pretty decent onboarding process.

Also they would occasionally have a day of the week where for an hour and a half or so someone might present some information on some technology giving an overview of it and maybe going through some simple operations. I enjoyed that since it was a way to get exposed to variety of other things.
cons:
I'd like to emphasize this only pertains to student workers as that is my only experience there and possibly applicants to a full time position. The experience might be different for salaried employees. 

If you are a CS major I highly suggest getting some intern experience elsewhere. Use this position as a jumping off point. I got a little complacent and after graduation I think it hurt me some that I only had experience here in applying to other jobs. You can still work here during the semester for some extra cash at least at the time of this reviews posting. There is also the possibility that you may get stuck on working on some older projects that might not be the most stimulating. Again why I suggest not relying solely on getting experience here.

I also applied for a full time position here several months after graduation. They were slow getting back to me although when they did they set up an in person interview fairly quickly. But afterwards they took a long time getting back to me with the results. I interviewed in late December and didn't hear anything until mid February. I sent follow up emails asking about the status of the position and never got a response. At least let me know that you are still deciding, going silent after an in person interview is not great in my opinion. It took prodding someone I know there to finally get a decision. Full disclosure I was rejected from the position. 

Also the in position interview process was a little odd compared to the other places I've interviewed. If I recall correctly there were 5-6 people in the room when interviewing me. The most I've had at other places is 3. Though I knew a couple people in the room it was still a little intimidating.  I think overall the interview was well run and organized, they had a list of questions to ask.

review_title: Overall a good place to work. Very laid back environment.
job_title: in College Park, MD
pros: The culture is very easy going and laid back. The benefits are very good including free education for your family  and a very generous 403 retired plan.
cons: The IT teams do not work together. The teams have a us against them mentality. Knowledge transfer between co-workers does not happen on a regular basis. Promotions and salary increases are far and in between.

review_title: OK Pay, but go elsewhere for better QoL/job satisfaction
job_title: Lecturer in College Park, MD
pros:
- Generous compensation for a state school salary
- A few very nice and professional coworkers
cons:
- Class size too large/inflexible policies. I taught 2 undergrad classes that were 60 - 80 students each. I didn't think this would be a problem at all, until I learned the school requires certain things be included as part of the syllabus for certain classes. For example a term paper. If I have to grade 80 15-20 page papers, I wanted to have the assignment be due a week or two before the semester ended. I was told that since it was a final assignment, I couldn't change the due date- it had to be due the day/time during which a final would be otherwise given. Long story short: I had 1 week to grade 80 term papers, and was not allowed to forego other work during the week to do it. 

- In my other class, I gave a final exam. These exams are scheduled to be 3hrs long. Several of my students came to me saying they had 2 3-hr exams prior. These poor kids would have been test-taking for 6 hours before they even got to my exam. When I filed a request to allow students to take it late/early, I was denied and told that there are too many instances of cheating when they do this.

-Another con: this job does not reimburse for local travel or expenses. Events I was required to attend out of state were not paid for, nor was comp time allowed. I was told "that's life, you can't nickel and dime everything". Now at my current job, I am encouraged to nickel and dime everything and be compensated fairly.

review_title: Great student part time job at UMD
job_title: Field Support- Division of IT (IDS) in College Park, MD
pros: Great people, staff, and fun to be around with. Should be quick to learn and it is a fairly easy job once you get the hang of it.  If you have a Test/paper, boss is really understanding and can let you take off because he knows you are a student first. Can lead to full time position if you have an IT background.
cons: Started with low pay, typically have to start as an underclassman for them to consider you because they want you to be there until you graduate.

review_title: Great place to work as an undergrad
job_title: Teaching Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: As a TA, the work was exciting. You get to talk about the subjects you love, and the more enthusiastic you are, the better it is.
cons: Sometimes the grading becomes a little intensive. You need to set aside more time than you'd expect to do it correctly.

review_title: A great organization that runs on the work of academic indentured servants
job_title: Research Associate in College Park, MD
pros: The University of Maryland has world-class resources, colleagues, and opportunities. It is a respected "name brand."
cons: However those perks come at the expense of long hours (expected), okay pay, and no room for internal advancement. There is a class hierarchy where tenured faculty dominant all conversations and agendas. It is better to say that you have worked there than to currently work there.

job_title: Enrollment Management Student Worker in College Park, MD
pros:
-great place to work if you need teamwork and like a friendly environment
-excellent hours and days off available
-supervisors are kind and generous with resources
-chance to grow into roles
cons:
-there is a lot of work and responsibility in the hands of student workers
-you start out at min. wage and stay there every year
-full time staffers often leave the negative work and problems for the students and are not all around when help is needed

job_title: Graduate Student in College Park, MD
pros: You get an education and pay. Lecturers treat graduate students well.
cons: Bad working conditions including working hours and the way other people treat you as a human. Bad pay. Most tenured professors do not care about graduate students only their success. Cannot form an union and resources to help students are either nonexistent or so inconvenient they are not worth the time. Graduated students are not getting good paying jobs. More people leave than complete the program.

review_title: Great benefits and not much else
job_title: Director in Adelphi, MD
pros: Great benefits for exempt (salaried) employees: Free tuition, five weeks vacation, retirement (immediate vesting), reasonable salaries. Relaxed atmosphere if you don't rock the boat. Relatively secure.
cons: Very poor, top-heavy management structure, poor communication, petty politics, obsessive focus on growth to the detriment of all that a university could and should be, tension between the academic and administrative branches of the university.

review_title: The University of Maryland is full of smart people and teeming with career opportunity.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in College Park, MD
pros: Excellent work-life balance; fair pay and good benefits (free tuition!); an environment that embraces diversity; great location on the Washington/Baltimore corridor (near DC); good transportation options (bike, walk, metro, buses). Maryland has a vibrant and intellectual student community, and the campus is gorgeous.
cons: In past years, state politicians have played Russian roulette with the state budget which resulted in employee pay freezes and furloughs several years running, though that was rare. The governor values higher education.

job_title: Assistant Research Professor in College Park, MD
pros:
- Good research environment
- Mostly recent laboratory infrastructure
- Depending on the lab, freedom to perform research
- Several common use scientific platforms (Fluorescence and live microscopy, flow cytometry, Electron microscopy, etc..)
- nice campus environment
cons:
- low pay after 7+ years with no prospects of significant increase
- parking fees for employees 
- transportation options centered around students instead of working staff

job_title: Community Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: UMD  fostered a supportive and friendly company wide culture. Management always takes the time to provide insight and training to its employees and really seem to value your input.  Awesome management, great training, highly competitive salary
cons: Nothing major.  Given the nature of being a community assistent you will find yourself working odd hours and juggling responsibility with classwork. Managers tend to understand this and provide support where possible.

review_title: Teaching Highly Valued Skills for Min Wage
job_title: Teacher Assistant in College Park, MD
pros:
Flexible work schedule for current students.
Remote work available depending on the agreements made with your professor .
cons:
Max hours is 20. This amount of time is difficult to finish tasks routinely, mainly grading. 
Professors are not authorized to increase max hours for their TAs.
Min to Zero training in usage of grading applications (elms). 
Zero benefits for part-time workers.
Employees are required to purchase a parking pass.

review_title: Nice place to refine your research ability
job_title: Research Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: Very great experience working here. Learned a lot new stuff in technical background. The research environment is very active and high level. Insurance plan for graduate students is pretty great - same level as the staff members.
cons: Sometimes the graduate students have too much workloads. Especially in the ECE department. Depends on the advisor/sponsor though. Should provide more housing space close to campus as well.

review_title: Good Starting Point, But Not Your Goal
job_title: Web Developer in College Park, MD
pros: Working for a university is always a good thing, you are surrounded by young people who are working on making themselves better and naturally that will spread throughout the campus. They are flexible with hours and have more of a laid back environment.
cons: Being a state school it seems like even the smallest decisions are always committee driven. That can lead to things not changing and or things changing just for change sake. Not to mention the titles are ridiculous.

review_title: A great place to learn and teach!
job_title: Teaching Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: There are some very engaging professors who love both their subject areas as well as adapting to the new kinds of students and technological implementations in the classroom and lecture environments.
cons: The structure of some departments is outdated; younger professors and department heads are working, however, on updating curriculums in a way that better coincide with what society expects.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in College Park, MD
pros: Opportunities for tuition remission for graduate level courses. The accessibility to the Washington DC metro line (College Park station). Camaraderie among staff within department.
cons: I have never had such negative recurring experiences with a campus Department of Transportation Services on a college campus. This department is overreaching and difficult to work with as an employee and with our students. The administration seems to do nothing to reign them in and provide reasonable expectations/guidance.

job_title: Operations Assistant in College Park, MD
pros:
Excellent flexibility to fit the needs of the student
Learned many useful hand skills for repairing machinery
Motivating staff
Friendly work environment
cons: It would have been better if students were able to take formal personal development classes like resume writing, leadership, time management skills, etc. Other than that, there really are no complaints.

job_title: Coordinator of Administrative Services in College Park, MD
pros: Excellent benefits (22 days off), plus sick, bereavement, personal days, annual and vacation (week off for Winter Break, 3 Days for Spring Break). Great atmosphere to work with. If you like working with students and intellectual people in a place that gives you the freedom to get involved on campus outside of job description. Many perks, from loan forgiveness for working at a public institution, 20% many campuses and off-campus deals for working at UMD, discounts to games, flexible if you have a family.
cons: Health insurance package could be better.

job_title: Assistant Professor in Baltimore, MD
pros: Good pay, good hours, job security, state benefits, most people seem happy, many people stay for years, children get tution benefits, can take free classes
cons: it's not Hopkins! not given a fair chance, parking stinks, traffic is terrible, crime is somewhat of an issue

review_title: Working for the flagship University of the State of Maryland is an honor and a privilege. This is a dynamic environment
job_title: Business Manager in College Park, MD
pros:
Free tuition for employee & immediate family members.
Great vacation, sick leave, & pension benefits.
Beautiful campus and discounted access to arts & sports events.
Discounts to the gyms and work-out facilities.
Good ideas are implemented.
cons:
Parking fees are substantial.
Traffic can be heavy getting to campus.
Not very many cons to working here. Work is interesting, people are easy to work with, campus is beautiful for walking.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in College Park, MD
pros: It's pretty chill. I'm only a workstudy student, so it depends on where you work. I'm in an office, where if its not that busy, i can basically take time to study a little bit. I really like it and for the most part, they are really flexible with the schedules because they know being a student comes first.
cons: It also depends on who you work for and with. Some places are more strict than others. Obviously being a student, it will take your time away. Nothing really too bad though.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in College Park, MD
pros: Laid back. State government employee benefits are attractive especially when you have family who can attend the school.
cons: Some measure of discrimination and old-school mentality of hierarchy in the work place. No room for career advancement based on merit and no reward for excellence.

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Greenbelt, MD
pros: Everyone was very friendly to work with and very easy going.  It was a very nice environment to work and there is always something new to learn.
cons: There were a few people that were not very friendly, but you have to overlook that.  Most of the co-workers were very nice.  The money is little less than the private industry, but your schooling is covered if you want to go back to school, which is a plus.

review_title: Served as a Graduate Teaching Assistant in the Dept of Biology
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: Great way to pay for school. Convenient to work at the same place where you take your classes. Only have to report to your scheduled labs and prep meetings, otherwise you can be anywhere grading papers/emailing students/etc throughout the week. In that regard, it beats a M-F 9-5 job.
cons: Grading is often incredibly time-consuming. If you are not familiar with the material for the course to which you are assigned, it will likely be difficult the first semester of teaching it.

job_title: Resident Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: They understand the balance between a student and a worker.  There are also a lot of departments to choose from and to get involved with.  if you are unsatisfied with certain people, you can find another group of professionals that are more suited for you.
cons: There is a lot of students. The competition is high because of the amount of students.  It is also hard to be recruited outside of the Mid Atlantic area.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Park, MD
pros:
location is great. Close to DC, inside the metra area, close to NIH, FDA, NASA etc... job opportunities are a lot.
Diversity here is also great, you will feel comfortable here no matter your background. 
Gym here is first-class. Very nice for fitness, practicing everyday and even professional training.
The whole atmosphere is very peaceful and joyful.
cons: safety around campus after late night is not very good. Try to live far away from university downtown.

review_title: Great workplace, painful bureaucracy, limited growth... and NO COLA/increments for 5 years
job_title: Faculty Research Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: UM has excellent employee benefits, including free tuition, health etc. Being in the WDC metro area also has its advantages, such as proximity to museums, activities and a choice of three airports.
cons: very painful to get any work done with the bureaucracy - four set of signatures to purchase a lab notebook, excessive overheads (bring in funding and give away 60% in overheads - wonderful), 80% of the buildings are antiques, with antique facilities, things are always breaking.

job_title: Director in College Park, MD
pros: Good benefits and a lot of flexibility if you are on the Faculty or Administrative side of things.  Great deal of autonomy to define your job as you go and fit it to your strengths, at least in my experience.
cons: Insane bureaucracy.  We've had salaries frozen for several years and furloughs.  There is an entrenched difference between "Faculty and Admin" and "Staff" - - Staff positions are like a permanent underclass, with few benefits and horrible inequities.

review_title: My experience here is varied day to day, great people, no egos!
job_title: Faculty Research Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: I like the diversity of research and the opportunities to train and learn more. I plan to take advantage of tuition remission at some point. Many of my peers do, and it is encouraged to do so! Working hours are flexible. Free shuttle bus network throughout campus.
cons: Not any that I can think of right now. Training is encouraged, work-life balance is great...maybe the health insurance cost is a little high compared with the previous place I worked....

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: The whole math department is very friendly. L. Washington to other people really want you to enjoy your experience at this department. Dr. Trivisa is also very helpful
cons: The staff is stretched. There are not enough people to deal with all the issues. One particular staff member, the one who works in the undergraduate office, is very rude. I thought I was the only one she was rude to, but turns out she is rude to everybody.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: It provides a diversity environment. It has advanced equipment. It encourages to you think about innovative techniques. It provides all kinds of financial aids.
cons: It is too focused on techniques, does not emphasize on improving social skills. It does not encourage you to look for a mentor, besides your advisor.

review_title: Very open work environment - allows for the exploration of creative ideas
job_title: Undergraduate Researcher in College Park, MD
pros:
If you have an idea and know how you want to test it out, it is up to you to put it into action.
Great communication between team members.
Great learning environment.
cons:
Research project directors could keep better track of projects and they move along.
The hourly pay was pretty average for an undergrad researcher.

review_title: Graduate research assistant-ship at UMD is challenging but rewarding
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: As a Research assistant you have independence and freedom in the lab. Lots of opportunities for training and learning new skills
cons: Finding good mentors can be challenging. Definitely need to seek help proactively to avoid getting left behind. Use your post-docs as resources!

job_title: Teaching Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: 1. Reputation - UMD has an excellent reputation, is a high-ranked school, and looks good on your resume
cons:
1. Overworked - you are expected to work longer hours than you are paid for 
2. Supervisor treatment - being stomped on, disrespected, and belittled is common across campus
3. Unprofessional Culture - if this were a company in the private sector, the majority of people that work here would have been fired long ago

review_title: Maryland is a good organization and the people there are excellent.
job_title: Teaching Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: The hourly wage may not be as good as one may like.  The people at the Business school are great and easy to talk to.  The community is great and it's easy to talk to people when help is needed.
cons: The pay could be a little higher.  There is not really too many cons except for pay, it's really a nice place to work and the people understand how to be good team players.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Hunt Valley, MD
pros: Pay is good, decent PTO off, flexible hours, optional overtime if we want it, relaxed dress code (aka jeans), no scheduled specific time for lunch, and option to work from home.
cons: Understaffed causing backlog of work. There are unreasonablely high expectations in terms of amount of work that should be done while still being held to high standards. Changes in management and procedures can cause confusion. Also, the A/C is cranked up so high year round that there are people running around in snuggies.

review_title: Good place for students to work while taking classes
job_title: Weight/Fitness Staff in College Park, MD
pros: Interacting with a diverse body of students makes working at the University of Maryland well worth it.
cons: Sometimes the management can be a little harsh. Though, really, most students have low professional expectations... when you work in the "real world", you have to work.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: Work isn't too much time consuming, is synchronised with Graduate Program (MSIS) for study. It helps revise key concepts of Google Analytics and the GOMC challenge, enables me for valuable Google certification as well.
cons: Some prior preparation was required to become a TA. Also entering the position was not a simple task. (but it paid off)

job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Washington, DC
pros: This is a review of the physics department at UMD. It is definitely a great place to work; I've made lifelong friends as a graduate research assistant here. The department is large with researchers at the top of their field in many different disciplines. The environment is friendly and professional. Its proximity to DC is nice -- College Park itself is also improving.
cons: I would not live in College Park itself; hard to get around without a car, even with school shuttles and public transportation.

job_title: Kitchen Supervisor in College Park, MD
pros: Nice group of management and employees. Clean work environment. Plenty of perks exist with food and such. Wide variety of food to work with to serve customers
cons: Stressful work environment. Work hours and restaurant business varies greatly depending on the time of the semester. It can be intensely busy or deathly slow. You can end on closing time or work 2-3 hours past closing time.

review_title: undergraduate experience as a research assitant
job_title: Research Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: Good to work in labs during school without going off campus especially for undergraduates. Sometimes you can get course credits along with being paid.
cons: It is not easy to land a job in laboratories, there is usually a waiting period. Also hard to find a lab that you like.

job_title: Assistant Research Scientist in College Park, MD
pros: You will find very good (i.e., skillful) collaborators for your research in engineering. The university has very good facilities to support your research, including the Neutral Buoyancy Research Facility (NBRF). The university also provides very good facilities to support your teaching. The staff people are usually very helpful. The campus is large and beautiful.
cons: The structure of the building does not allow to have windows in a lot of labs. The high crime rate of the area around campus.

job_title: Aerospace Engineering Research Assistant in Sherman, CT
pros: Flexible hours, driven and intelligent co-workers, access to high quality tools and resources, fantastic learning environment both educationally and for the real world.
cons:
- Trying to find a place to park if you don't live close to campus can be a hassle
- A low hourly wage for the importance of work

job_title: Librarian in College Park, MD
pros: Great benefits and there are a lots of smart and friendly people to work with. Getting access to free software like Photoshop is an awesome side benefit.
cons: The problem with UMD is the great deal of bureaucracy that comes with a large state university. The area around the campus isn't really that great and you always get police reports of armed and unarmed robberies in the area late at night. Not the best salaries compared to the expensive DC area.

review_title: A nice comprehensive university which still has space for improvement
job_title: Research Assistant in Rockville, MD
pros:
The campus is large and beautiful.
There are many convenient facilities and services, such as library, art center, gym and transportation.
There are many excellent academic communities in various subjects and interdisciplinary cooperation.
cons:
College park is not a very good location for university.
Although there is shuttle service between the main campus and other campus scattered around DC and Maryland, the commuting sometimes can be distressing
Research funding is not ample for some fields such as Biology.

review_title: An Okay experience, but do not have too many high hopes.
job_title: Graduate Assistant in College Park, MD
pros:
Healthcare benefits, tuition remission--which is extremely important for non-resident students--you can save tuition as well as your health insurance monthly payment.

The school has many opportunities--keep an eye on job posts and you will find some. Or talk to professors.
cons: Although opportunities abound, you need to figure out where and when. Job posts are not very well maintained--they should have taken down posts that are already filled.  Need more communication to the students.

job_title: Graduate Assistant in Hyattsville, MD
pros: It was a great way to supplement my income while I was a graduate student there at the business school. The hour were flexible
cons: I sometimes felt that my supervisors, two professors, did not care too much about student happiness. Often times students would come into my office at the last minute and expect me to do their homework.

job_title: Analyst in College Park, MD
pros:
a) senior management appreciates your contribution
b) work-life balance - management is considerate of employee's needs
c) opportunity to take on leadership roles
cons:
a) Not enough opportunities for career advancement 
b) Confined to roles - not being able to expand understanding of industry which is understandable given the nature of the industry itself

review_title: I enjoy doing research here with state-of-the-art equipments a lot.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Park, MD
pros:
Free working atmosphere.
Good research and entertainment facilities.
Nice people.
Overall, this school is a very good environment for students or employers to develop themselves.
cons:
The campus and neighborhood of this school are notorious for its safety issues in the night. 
Parking fee terribly increases year by year.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: Freedom to do research at your own pace (depends on advisor really), good courses and beautiful campus. Shuttle service for student transport is excellent. Proximity to DC is a plus.
cons: Research can be frustrating at times, switching from RA to TA and the changes in pay happen without notice and changes have to be made accordingly in your lifestyle. Sketchy neighborhood and dull surroundings in College Park don't help. Super expensive housing anywhere surrounding the campus for something decent.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: Great benefits, a ton of PTO, good work life balance, job security.
cons: Vast majority of the administrative support staff paid well below market rates, there's no upward mobility, a lot of red tape to be expected, not challenging work (except learning to cut through the bureaucratic bs), boring place to work in terms of day to day operations but if you like consistency then you'd love it, overall most people there a very nice and friendly to work with.

job_title: TA, Math in College Park, MD
pros: Lots of freedom to choose hours, research topics, advisors, and so on. Health insurance is good. Teaching load is fairly low.
cons: Pay is not great, and it's hard to predict what your job will be. Also the building is falling apart because they don't maintain anything, just build new buildings when the old ones die.

job_title: Bus Driver in College Park, MD
pros: By working at Shuttle-UM, I was able to pick flexible hours to help pay for tuition. They paid for my CDL Training, which I can now take anywhere
cons: Management seems to be more reactionary than proactive. They often make decisions without factoring in how the workforce has to implement it

review_title: Good place to work, understanding bosses
job_title: Cashier in College Park, MD
pros: Bosses and coworkers were flexible with shifts that needed to work around my academic schedule. Pay was good compared to off campus jobs. Location was close to where I spend most of my days.
cons: Limited growth for reaching higher positions meant little potential for higher pay. Decision input of lower workers was considered but decisions were ultimately made by bosses, sometimes against employee consensus.

job_title: Communications Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: Working in the offices as a student can be pretty awesome because they understand that you're a student and are juggling both work and a job.  Get great experience as  a student because they try to shape your experience based on what you want.
cons: It can be a little disappointing when you have work scheduled during a huge campus event. But that's life.

job_title: Enforcement Specialist in Baltimore, MD
pros: Secure place of employment.  Convenient far as the location. Good place for keeping a stable job. They offer overtime.    The benefits package is good. Especially if you are going to school.
cons: The pay is not enough.  You have to do overtime to earn a good pay check.  Without doing overtime you'll be broke.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: I've attended College Park as a grad student for the last ~6 years (currently in final stretch of Ph.D) and I love it here. Of course, it is general knowledge that grad students don't earn a lot, and that's OK. I receive tuition remission as a graduate research assistant which helps pay most of my fees, so it's a great package overall.
cons: To be honest, none! Its a great environment for growing in one's career.

job_title: Faculty Research Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: As a young college graduate, I appreciated the comfort of being around college students my age. I liked being on a collegiate schedule with consistent holidays and a light summer. Opportunities to network with like minded people.
cons: I was only there for 1 year and worked in a small behavioral science research lab, so I didn't have much interaction with other departments.

job_title: Graduate Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: Great research university. Great support for those who want to get involved in research. Fair amount of activities, outreach to community. Access to Baltimore and Washington DC.
cons: College park is a waste of a college town, but at least they are working on changing that. Also, conservative politics keep people from addressing issues with sexual harassment and racism immediately. Also, as of yet, they have not allowed adjuncts and graduate students from forming a union.

job_title: in College Park, MD
pros: Great position and experience. If you like teaching the this is the job for you. I advise everyone to try to do this.
cons:
Low pay
Time consuming 
Trainings are long and don't really help
First session will be difficult but once you device a method it will be great

job_title: Teaching Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: Great work, great compensation for a student, and an excellent experience overall as an undergraduate student.
cons: Exam grading sometimes takes away time for studying for other exams, as it must be done same-day or day after the exam took place (not required to skip your exams if they interfere, of course).

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: Extensive facilities for most fields. Professors are looking to work with their graduate students and assist with their research to a large extent.
cons: Classes at an undergraduate level can be very large, making contact with teachers difficult and inhibiting learning opportunities. Becomes more manageable at higher levels where class size shrinks.

review_title: Good place to work for a few years
job_title: Research Associate in College Park, MD
pros: Good projects, benefits, overall positive work environment, other groups help in case of projects, people are not as snobbish considering the rank of the university.
cons: Low on work space, parking is expensive. Not much career options for researchers.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in College Park, MD
pros: Postdocs have a lot of resources to help them further their careers (interview and resume support etc.). State medical insurance seems fine. Very pleasant working environment. Nice campus. Fairly easy to get to.
cons: Postdoc positions in the US generally don't pay all that well. And while College Park is relatively cheap, if you want to live in the centre of DC, the costs go way up, so you won't have a lot of spare cash.

review_title: A place where you can learn and engage in organizational activities
job_title: Graduate Assistant in College Park, MD
pros:
Good Management,  Colleagues are good to work with. Information sharing is encouraged.
Good benefits.
Learning opportunities.
Responsibilities are equally divided.
cons: Working at a university won't provide more exposure to the corporate world. The process can be improved and time-lines should be made more strict.

review_title: Like many employers, your ability to succeed professionally depends on what department you work in.
job_title: Coordinator in Rockville, MD
pros: There's usually a place to grab coffee or a bite if you're hungry.
cons: The pay is very low, especially at the satellite locations.  To give an example, they want an employee with at least five years' relevant experience AND a master's degree, all for a whopping 32k per year with restricted benefits.

job_title: Compliance Coordinator in College Park, MD
pros: The University of Maryland, College Park is the flagship institution in the DMV area.  It's a great institution of higher learning and you're given the opportunity to learn and improve.
cons: When it comes to being given the opportunity and the teaching tools to train, that doesn't always happen if you're not in the inner circle.

review_title: It's a big business without the business.
job_title: Lecturer in College Park, MD
pros: Large degree of control over your own time.  Access to electronic library resources.  Stable employer.  Interesting work.  Good benefits.  Good name.
cons: Bureaucracy of academics.  Endless special activities that interfere with parking.  Lack of transparency in policies and decisions.  Little opportunity for growth.

job_title: Lead Technologist in Baltimore, MD
pros: Good place to work instead ?
cons:
Supervisor does not have full knowledge and experienced to run lab, also she does not have real manner to talk to the workers.
She has master degree don't know which subject from USA, so they hire her as Supervisor. 
She act as illiterate. Management have complete knowledge and are involve but never take any action about it.

job_title: Math Tutor in College Park, MD
pros:
Flexible work hours 
Friendly coworkers and boss
The job was enjoyable and relaxing as it is a step away from normal college activities.
cons:
The training sessions were ineffective and very boring. 
The management system is very strict .
There is a lot of waste time during work.

review_title: Wonderful institution but struggles to incorporate graduate student needs
job_title: Graduate Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: Environment is friendly. Fellow graduate students in government and politics are fun and hard-working.
cons: Funding for graduate students is below our peers, and far below what is required to meet our departmental aspirations.

job_title: Manager in College Park, MD
pros: Good benefits, good time off. The staff members in my department are a pleasure to work with. There are a lot of advancement opportunities.
cons: Salaries are not competitive for the area. The health insurance premiums are pretty high, and I do not think they are in-line with the rest of their benefits.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: A great school with lots of opportunities around. Lots of grants to keep many of the graduate students on for long periods of time. Graduate research is held at a very high standard.
cons: Departments do not care for the graduate student's well-being. Focus will always be on the faculty and staff before the student, and most of the time policies that are in place hurt the student more than it helps.

job_title: Senior Research Scientist in College Park, MD
pros: Great opportunities for inter-disciplinary research, upper management committed to career enhancement, generous comprehensive benefits package, extensive network of contacts to decision makers in R&D in nearby federal government funding agencies and laboratories, availability of highly qualified faculty and graduate research assistants.
cons: I have never experienced any cons.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Baltimore, MD
pros: The University of Maryland School of Medicine offers a good benefit package; however no retirement benefits as a postdoctoral fellow. Campus has recreational facilities
cons: No retirement benefits are included in the postdoctoral fellow salary. Campus is in West Baltimore, which can get dangerous, especially after dark and on weekends when police presence is low

review_title: nice place to live and to study
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant (Physics) in College Park, MD
pros: Get the chance to work with many great physicists and many smart people. There are many seminars and talks and a lot of discussions. Very good academic environment.
cons: Some of the student offices don't have windows. There are many undergraduate students going there and looking for classroom, which is very annoying.

job_title: Graduate Assistant in Topsfield, MA
pros:
Good benefits for employees (i.e. health insurance, sick days)
Supervisors have been very supportive and understanding of the time commitment of graduate school
cons:
Sometimes work comes at inopportune times
Often responsibilities are not outlined, structured, or communicated properly, resulting in the expectation of accomplished tasks which were not made clear

job_title: Research Assistant in Greenbelt, MD
pros: Professors are nice and the students are mostly hardworking. Enhance your knowledge on the topics covered in the class. Provide credit remission and in-state tuition rate.
cons: Depending on the course, some courses (e.g. programming) has a heavy workload during office hours since you have to solve all kinds of questions.

review_title: You have to be tough to work in the Sutudent Financial Services Department at UMBC
job_title: Accountant
pros: The benefits were good and you also got chance to go to school for free.
cons: The pay was bad. People quit in my department all the time and the senior management just re- distributed the workload. We were all behind in one area or another because we were ALWAYS short staffed

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: Outstanding academic environment peopled with researchers and academics who are tops in their fields.  The University is growing in all of the right ways.
cons: It's situated in an area known for having problems with criminal activity.  It's also in an area that is relatively high cost.

job_title: Student Affairs in College Park, MD
pros:
Generous benefits, particularly about families
Flexible time 
Well trained co-workers
Very, very inclusive culture
Given the job responsibilities, compensation in the administration is very high.
cons:
Slow and cumbersome to enact change within the admin.
Inefficient use of resources
This sounds odd, but its a very female dominate culture.  In meetings, men are often out-numbered 3 or 5 to one.

job_title: Tutor in Washington, DC
pros: Nice colleagues, friendly supervisor, flexible topic and content. Students are not very hard to teach, you can always share your opinions with them.
cons: time schedule is firm. No working at home allowed. Even if you are really busy with your curriculum, you can't reschedule to weekends or nights.

job_title: in College Park, MD
pros: The University is a good place to work with a lot of opportunities for research, teaching and collaboration. Colleagues and supervisors are also congenial and easy to work with.
cons: Does not pay enough for livable wages to graduate assistants; terms and conditions should be improved for students to appeal to broader talent.

review_title: Good part time job for UMD students
job_title: Student Ambassador in College Park, MD
pros:
Flexibility, you get to choose the days you want to work, except on the days you have to come in. 
Good pay as compared to other on and off campus jobs.
You get to talk with various alumni about their experience.
cons:
Lots and lots of cold calling.
Management could be more understanding.
Most hires leave pretty soon after starting.

job_title: Communications Coordinator in College Park, MD
pros: Great work life balance, excellent supervisor, health benefits are the best I have seen of my offers and with friends I have compared with, good vacation time, allowed to work from home approx 2-4x per month.
cons: sometimes the work pace is a little slow, not always enough to do. Parking could be closer to the buildings employees work in. You should not have to pay for parking as an employee.

job_title: Development Coordinator in College Park, MD
pros: Great culture, and has the best people to work with! Super flexible, best benefits ever. It's like 22 days PTO, 15 days sick, and holidays off.
cons: In order to move up, you most likely have to change positions in another department or unit since they don't really promote. Only way to get more pay in your current position is to get reclassified (doesn't happen often) or if there's a statewide COLA in Maryland.

review_title: More than the institution, it's the individual you work for/with that matters most
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: Access to academics, working on projects without having to win the funding, library.
cons: The level of inter-departmental collaboration is low.

job_title: Graduate Student in College Park, MD
pros: I'm getting a PhD so working here is a means to an end.  I'm off campus so I don't really know what happens on campus.  People seem nice in general.  I go on campus occasionally and its what you would expect.
cons: Salary is relatively low.  Professors don't take many people.  Over inflated administration.  Like I said I'm off campus so I don't know much about the culture

job_title: Anonymous Employee in College Park, MD
pros: Flexible work schedule. They offer good benefits through the state of Maryland. As faculty and staff member, you can your family can also do courses for free.
cons: Not a good neighborhood to stay or hang out as compared to many other college towns. The commute is also bad.

review_title: Good experience working as a graduate student
job_title: Research Assistant in Arlington, VA
pros: My experience as a TA and RA has been as good as can be expected at UMD, College Park.
cons: Most of the cons of working as a graduate student are present but aren't specific to this university. As best as I can tell the pay here is typical or better than average for prominent research institutions. Working as a TA is not a job anyone wants permanently.

review_title: Great benefits, but offset by lower pay
job_title: Assistant Director in College Park, MD
pros: Great benefits, generous paid vacation leave and sick leave, access to cultural activities on campus, diverse workforce
cons: Hard to get promoted when senior managers stay in their positions for a long time, some long-term employers seem unmotivated, lack of pay/cost of living increases due to tight state budgets

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: Exposure to different research topics, opportunities to collaborate with researchers well known in their field. As a typical academic environment, it provides some flexibility regarding work hours. Friendly people.
cons: Depending on your supervisor, you may be closely supervised or not supervised at all. The recent economic downturn has affected the day-to-day operations (e.g. fewer open labs to students to work).

review_title: great opportunity to do good work
job_title: Research Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: This is a fine place to do research and grow as an engineer. Good faculty, courses and very good funding.
cons: Sometimes faculty advisors can be tyrants and expect you to slave for them. All depends on who you work with.

review_title: not a good place for graduate students
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: Great locations; Baltimore -DC area is a huge plus for this University. A lot of potential opportunities;  A lot of fun from nearby place.
cons: Not safe; As a public university, the pay is too low, especially for some engineering student; campus is too large and sometimes boring; the location is the largest Pros; adviser has too much influence on student

review_title: Great place to work and learn
job_title: Research Assistant in College Park, MD
pros: Great environment, flexible hours, pay came on time, worked with leaders in their field, was part of important research and publications.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in College Park, MD

cons:
All persons I've spoken with in HR, FSAP, Union rep, Title IX rep, former CDO, and Thriving Workplace all have advised me to seek employment elsewhere because the culture of UMD will not change. Racism will remain, and upper management will remain bullies. This is so sad for a new employee. There is no diversity in upper management. There is no fair pay. Everyone is either low or mid level employees. There's no means for a raise bc we are state employees. The DiamondBack publishes salaries and it REALLY hits home how much LESS you make even though you have more responsibility than others. There's no response from leadership despite the CLEAR TOLL it takes on morale. Telework is for upper management ONLY PERIOD. No one will even consider allowing extended work days [i.e 4-10hr days w/ 1 day off]. Parking will get WORSE. Metro is NOT accessible where we LIVE. I live 30 mins away if I took the metro my commute would be 1.5hrs. Plus Metro is HORRIBLE. 

Finally at this PWC, the money is the most important. So if you're in finance you are good, you will be paid. The rest of us are only here for free tuition so see how much you can put up with while getting your degree or putting your kids thru school. Honestly I have a Sr in HS and now that I've been here i don't want my kid going to a school like this.. The only interest they have is athletics.
